title: How to get inspired for composing a piece of music - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, that’s an interesting question, and one whose answer is going to depend on why you’re asking. I’m speaking from my own personal experience here, but I firmly believe that, if you are an inherently creative person, there isn’t a force in the world that could stop you from creating - you write poems or prose, you draw or paint, you write music or perform it… creativity is like an energy that must be released or it feels as though it might just pop you like a balloon. If you’re that type of person, and you’re feeling uninspired at the moment, don’t sweat it! Sometimes inspiration takes a holiday, but never fear, your muse will return, and you’ll find inspiration again. The thing to do is to let your mind and heart be open, observe the things around you as you go through your daily life with interest, and something will tweak your creativity and you’ll be off. If you’re not an inherently creative person - if, for example, you’ve never found yourself doing something creative (writing, drawing, composing, whatever…) at 4 in the morning, with no idea how you got there, because you’re last coherent thought about the time was from the early afternoon the previous day (some people call this being “in the zone”, I call it “getting trampled by the muse”) - then your task is to find inspiration and it’s a little tougher. My mentor in composition, the great Michel Rochon, gave me a trick that I’ve used on several occasions when I had a commission or something that I couldn’t get inspired for (the muse can be fickle), and it’s resulted in some successful pieces: set yourself some rules within which you must make your composition work. They can be anything, one example that I used was that each instrument or section in the orchestra could play only one note - they could play it long or short, loud, soft, repeated as many times as necessary but each instrument or section was “stuck” on that one note. The rule(s) that you set will impose certain restrictions on how you compose the piece (with my rule, for example, in order to create any melody, I had to “sequence” different instruments, having one play after the other). It will give your technical mind something to grapple with, and hopefully ignite your creativity, necessity being the mother of invention.

There are a couple approaches you can take. APPROACH 1: Biographical/Historical Write down 2–3 important events from your life or history. Think about the emotional tone and themes of these events. What did the emotional journey look like? Where did it start, where did it end up? Map out your experience of the event and use that as the form for your piece. Choose key centers or notes/patterns that reflect your relationship with that event. Start to develop your ideas and keep returning to the event(s) for inspiration. APPROACH 2: Music You Already Love Make a short list of music that you love listening to, say 5 songs. Next to each song, write one thing you love about it. Maybe it’s the beat, or the lyrics, or the crazy way the trombone player blares a solo. Now take those characteristics, and start to combine them. Make a mash up. It’s the beat from “Everybody Dance Now” with the melody line from “Happy”, but in a different key, and with the emotional character of Shostakovich symphony #10 movement 2. Use these musical qualities and inspirations as building blocks for a unique mash up piece. You know what composer Igor Stravinsky supposedly said, “A good composer does not imitate; he steals”. APPROACH 3: Forget Inspiration and Just Work Books like The War of Art talk about just showing up. Don’t insist on inspiration to do the work. Just set a timer for 30 minutes and write whatever you can. “Write for the trash can”. Eventually if you keep showing up you’ll produce quality output. Get Organized and Stay Focused Use timers and a notepad, or a music practice app like Modacity, to allocate time for different activities. Maybe you want to try all 3 approaches and give yourself 20 minutes for each one. Stay in touch with a clear purpose for why you are writing music - be it self-expression, or giving something beautiful to others, or just to celebrate how cool music is. Your purpose will help you create more.

I’m not a professional composer but I write music at a fairly prolific rate and I get my inspiration from just about everywhere. I literally can’t help it. For me the key to being constantly inspired is being able to recognise ideas in a variety of ways. When I’m listening to a song/film score etc I explore everything within it. I’ve been doing this my whole life, for decades before I even started to learn to play & write music myself. It’s that “training” that created an endless source of inspiration I now use. When I listen to music, I listen to the individual instruments, the melodies, the layering and mixing of the different sounds, the dynamics, the rhythms, the structure, the tones, the space, the drops & hit sections, the combinations, the effects & so much mire. Not just the “school” list that we’re taught to hear which is important too (timbre etc) but the individual and combined ideas that can be literal eg a specific melody or more obscure eg the melody or rhythm two instruments are making when heard together in one part of a song, the way specific reverb affects the overall mood etc. Each single idea (hundreds in every song) has the potential to go on to be the seed new song or musical piece in its own right or to enhance or change an existing one. They are my inspiration & it’s endless. It’s all about ideas and the ability to recognise, expand and explore them. If any single element of a musical piece can be inspiring by itself then it’s impossible to ever run out of inspiration. For me anyway. What I don’t have is enough time or the playing/writing skills to explore them all but I’m getting there a little more each day.

Birds, mostly. And other stuff. I guess. Oh, and snakes! Snakes are pretty cool. Nature in general. I write a lot of nature music. It helps that I live in the mountains, surrounded by birds and snakes. Not literally. That would be a terrifying existence, no matter how much I love birds and snakes. I’d have to force my way through feathers and scales just to get to my composing desk! Actually, I’m pretty sure I just write about stuff that’s around me, in general. I’ll see some crows hanging out by the music building, and say, “Ooh, crows are the best bird, I bet some neat crow tunes are in order.” Or I’ll be in the middle of an infatuation with some girl and use that week of new-crush-feelings to write some sappy love-dovey music. Or I’ll read an answer on Quora about exploding stars and lethal paperclips, and go to write a really epic full orchestra showstopper with booming timpani and roaring brass! And then I’ll get distracted reading more Quora answers, and forget what I was doing in the first place. Sometimes I’ll hear a song that catches my ear, and I’ll write something with that in mind. Mondays and Thursdays, I write more jazz, because I have jazz band rehearsals those mornings. Sometimes I have cool ideas for really big projects, but most of the time, those stay as ideas, because I don’t have the time or patience to work on them piece-by-piece. I just want two months where I can just live in front of my work station and knock out all of my tarot card pieces, and my New-Orleans-jazz adaptation of The Magic Flute, and my seven-birds symphony, and my dream memoirs, and all the other wacky blueprints rattling around in my noggin at any given moment. But mostly, birds. Yup. Birds are neat.

A lot of people say a variation of lucidness, like inner mind, transcendental peace, or otherly imagine. Bullsh**. Like all art, we build on top of what is already there. Everything we've heard, everything we've liked, the things we dislike. What seems like pure imagination is just our magical brains reconstituting patterns in the primate way it evolved to do. The skill of a music writer (composing includes skills beyond music writing that aren't relevant here) lies in their discretion of these patterns. Anyone that tells you their piece came to them in a dream is either lying or has an objectively awful piece of work. But their inspirations can very well come from something natural. Inspiration is just 1% of the work needed to write music.

I like to make a distinction between inspiration and motivation when it comes to writing music. If someone asks me what inspires me to write, I never quite know what to say. But if someone asks me to describe what motivates me, I feel that that’s a question I can answer. That’s because most of the writing I do these days is because I’ve been asked to do it, not specifically because I feel inspired. That doesn’t mean that I don’t get excited about composing, of course. When someone says that they’d like for me to compose something, let’s say, for their choir, for a performance on a certain date, I feel highly motivated, and I find that musical ideas start popping into my mind, even at that beginning stage. It doesn’t take much to get me excited about writing. If that’s what you call inspiration, then I guess I’m inspired.

The act of actually sitting down to work, even when I have no ideas, is what sort of “primes the pump”. Waiting for inspiration is a recipe for producing absolutely nothing. Inspiration comes during work. Once something comes up in an improvisation, or when just throwing ideas on paper, that may become the germinating starting point. A great way of exploring this “technique” is to study Beethoven’s sketch books. You can often see just how he developed and expanded on simple ideas that he jotted down and began working on. As others have written here, yes, something like a good piece of music might inspire me, but only in the sense that it might inspire me to work.

It varies a lot. It depends on the mood I am in. But remember, in a composition, especially like the one I am specializing in, the Concerto for piano and orchestra, this is always an ongoing process. One cannot compose the entire piece, including the three movements, ( sometimes four) in a single day. So, I apply a principle that never fails me. I work on it. I change a passage. I change a substitution chord for an other, I change an instrument for an other, change the tempo, add or delete a repetition, sometimes, get tired of that composition. So, I let it rest for some times. A day, a week, I even went to a full years before restarting to work on it with new ideas. And so on. Slowly but surely, the piece takes a more and more definite form. And some more corrections. Often, I start the second movement before finishing the first. Sometimes even an other Concerto because suddenly I heard it in my head. IN a nutshell. there is no very short answer to this question. There are so many ways you get inspired. But, something for sure, I need some form of compulsion and obsession and desire to render it as beautiful as I can. Sometimes though it comes a lot easier, especially in shorter pieces such as a Rondo or a Scherzo since there are many repetition that are part of this form. Sometimes, the form is very loose such as in a rhapsody or a fantasy. I am fairly sure that should you ask this question to several composer, the answer is going to be the same.

The same things that inspire poets, painters, novelists, sculptors, people in almost any creative line of endeavor. Love, death, beauty, fear… life. In this case, whatever it is just happens to come out as music.

I've been inspired by the sound of a broken fan, a bathtub dripping, the tones of people's conversations, and other semi random occurrences. Sometimes when I'm working beautiful music suddenly flows through me but I never get a chance to notate it. Also during emotional situations or road trips and adventures music might spring up out of nowhere in my imagination.

It’s artistry and the required almost mathematical nature as well. 2. Literally everything. I find music within everything all around me. From the melodies of the wind in the trees to the bustle streets of the cities; to the voices I hear in the background of a TV show; to the lies people tell; and I even hear squirrels and other animals writing harmonies. Music isn't about finding your own sound, it's using the melodies all around you and transforming it into something capable of starting wars and bringing tears. It's a powerful tool anyone can use, it's just a matter of listening to your own world.

Lots of composers, in lots of different ways. Beethoven for his sheer bloody-mindedness and power - though not because of the music all that much. Ravel for his classiness. Suave, cool, elegant, beautiful, economical. Stravinsky for his inventiveness. Always something new, always something different, and always something incredibly well thought-out. Debussy for his textures. Tchaikovsky for his orchestration. John Cage for his attitude. Rameau for his weirdness. Monteverdi for radical spirit and the melodic invention.

According to Shostakovich’s Testimony, a friend of Shostakovich’s asked Shostakovich, “How do I get inspired to write the first movement of my new symphony?” Shostakovich answered, “don’t wait for inspiration. Just write the first movement.”

Among the greatest composers, it was almost always money or the hope for money. The cases where someone, past the childhood learning stage, wrote something just to write it are rare. Bach, Mozart, Beethoven, Haydn… they either had steady jobs as composers, or wrote on specific commissions from interested musicians or wrote their music to sell to publishers. It was their job. Fortunately for us, they were good at it.

Many things - Sometimes it can be a mood or a ‘feeling’. Sometimes a word or a phrase. Sometimes just a photograph or painting. Sometimes just a look from someone on the street. Sometimes just a simple two or four bar melody that sneak in and haunts me until I flesh it out.

Oftentimes it’s a melody or sound that appeared out of nowhere in my head. Other times it is with an instrument in hand that a note, chord, rhythm, or quality of sound appears that strikes the ear. After either of these, the hunt begins to decode what exactly it is and what kind of musical world it wants to live in.

Mostly nature, the universe and mythology. I am also socially conscious and from time to time write compositions aimed at making an emotional comment on topics such as war, environmental destruction and ethnic diversity.
Songs that have a reason for example, How To Save A Life… by the Fraye…it has meaning, so many ppl are committing suicide, they have no one who hears them!!

Anger, love, hate, all the usual stuff. If I have a run in with someone, I'll usually vent by writing it into a song and talking about them or the situation in a vague way. If I feel that I am writing too much negativity, I flip the theme and make it opposite. That sometimes works, but not all the time.

Feelings, of course. To a woman, to God, to the country, to mom. A greatest composers per se are those, who keep their feelings packaged into awesome and perfectly constructed form. Motivated great composer is emotionaly engaged.
I have no idea where inspiration comes from. it just happens sometimes.
